name: Drowning
description: Water submersion emergency requiring immediate rescue

steps.text: Ensure your own safety first: Do not enter water unless trained. Use reach-throw-row-go method. Throw flotation device or extend pole/towel
Call 911 immediately or direct a bystander to call while you begin rescue
Remove from water: Support head and neck if diving injury suspected. Get person horizontal and onto firm surface
Check responsiveness: Tap shoulders, shout 'Are you okay?' Look for chest rise, listen for breathing for no more than 10 seconds
Begin rescue breathing: If not breathing but has pulse, give 1 rescue breath every 5-6 seconds. Recheck pulse every 2 minutes
Begin CPR if no pulse: 30 chest compressions then 2 breaths. Push hard and fast, 2 inches deep, 100-120 per minute. Do not stop
Continue until: Person responds, AED arrives, trained help takes over, or you are physically exhausted
Prevent hypothermia: Remove wet clothing, cover with blankets. Even if person seems fine, insist on medical evaluation

name: Near Drowning
description: Person rescued from water who is breathing

steps.text: Prioritize spinal precautions: If person dove, fell, or mechanism unknown, assume spinal injury. Keep head, neck, and spine aligned
Remove from water carefully: Use backboard if available. Multiple rescuers should coordinate to keep spine aligned
Call 911: All near-drowning victims need hospital evaluation. Secondary drowning can occur hours later from water in lungs
Position for breathing: If no spinal injury suspected, place in recovery position (on side) to prevent aspiration if vomiting occurs
Monitor continuously: Watch for changes in consciousness, breathing difficulty, or coughing. Note time in water if known
Prevent hypothermia: Remove wet clothing, wrap in blankets, move to warm environment. Even warm water can cause hypothermia
Stay with victim: Condition can worsen suddenly. Do not leave alone until EMS arrives and takes over care
